September is suicide prevention month. Students from Questar III's New Visions: Visual & Performing Arts program, in cooperation with the Rensselaer County Suicide Prevention Task Force, created this public service announcement to educate the community on the signs. This PSA, titled The Signs, was created by high school seniors as part of an accelerated half-day program based at the Arts Center of the Capital Region.

If you or a loved one needs help, please call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255. Free support is available 24/7 in English and Spanish.

This will be especially important for our 100% virtual students. Students who are participating in our hybrid program, who are not able to come to this pick-up, will receive their device in advisory during one of the first days of in-person instruction.

If you have any questions, please contact the HS at 674-7002.

Algonquin Middle School has a new secretary in the main office in Kim Drischler.

Mrs. Drischler has worked in the Averill Park Central School District for more than 10 years, starting as a substitute teacher aide before being a full-time classroom teacher aide at Algonquin.

“Both of my children attended, and graduated from, Averill Park and have since graduated from college and started careers,” she said. “The flexible hours of subbing early on worked well with raising a family.”

Over the past 10 years, Mrs. Drischler has enjoyed working in all of the APCSD buildings, getting to know many of the students and faculty members.

“I always found working in the classroom to be very rewarding when you are able to help a student achieve their goals,” she said. “Algonquin is a wonderful place to work and I am excited to be working in the main office as the Secretary to the Vice Principal. I am looking forward to a whole new set of challenges and the opportunity to help and get to know so many more of our faculty, students and parents.”

Residents of the Averill Park Central School District approved a $60.9 million budget for the 2020-21 school year by a vote of 2,668 (yes) to 1,246 (no), a margin of 68 percent. Voters also approved a separate bus purchase proposition.

Averill Park residents also voted for two open seats on the Board of Education. Elected to the Board is Ann M. Morone with 2,298 votes and Douglas Kelley with 2,139. D.J. Hansen also ran and finished with 1,995 votes.

To read more, visit: https://www.averillpark.k12.ny.us/news-archive-2019-2020/4275-residents-approve-2020-2021-school-budget-elect-board-members

Thank you, Averill Park, for helping to make this happen!

NOTICE:

In a neighboring school district, an individual was reported to be visiting homes, fraudulently posing as an employee of that district in an attempt to collect chromebooks.

At this time, we are unaware of this happening in the Averill Park Central School District, but we want our community to be aware of the situation. At no time will anyone from the district be visiting homes to collect devices.

Students in grades 6-9 will keep their chromebooks at home over the summer and bring them back to school in the fall. Students in grades K-5 who borrowed a device during the COVID-19 pandemic should be returning it to school on either June 19 or June 22 from 9 a.m. – Noon or 4-6 p.m. The High School is collecting technology on June 16 and June 17 from 9 a.m. - Noon and 1-6 p.m.

If anyone comes to your home to collect a chromebook, do not give it to them. If this does occur, please call your local police department to report the incident.

Lilly Kronau, Xander Michaels and Carley Salerno achieved their New York State Seal of Biliteracy in Spanish graduation distinction this week.

All three gave presentations on inspirational people from the Spanish speaking world. Lilly focused on artists, Xander on soccer players and Carley on singers.

Evaluating their presentations were Dr. Alejandra Bronfman (Depatrment Chair of Latinos and Caribbean Studies department), Carmen Nieves (Phd candidate at SUNY Albany) and Ildefonso Apelanz (Phd candidate at SUNY Albany). All evaluators are native Spanish speakers.

Students presented their research and then answered questions from the evaluators.

Felicitaciones to all on this extraordinary achievement!

Yearbook signing

Governor Andrew M. Cuomo issued an Executive Order on Sunday, June 7 extending the deadline to submit absentee ballots for the School Budget vote and Board of Education Election.

To be counted, all hand-delivered ballots must still be received by the District by 5:00 p.m. on Tuesday, June 9. All ballots submitted after June 9 will be accepted only by mail and must be received via mail by Tuesday, June 16. We encourage anyone who wishes to vote to return their absentee ballot as soon as possible to ensure it is received in time.

Please follow all instructions on the ballot and be sure to include your name, address and signature on the return envelope. Failure to include the necessary information will void the ballot.

For more information on the 2020-2021 school budget and for bios on the candidates running for the Board of Education, visit: https://www.averillpark.k12.ny.us/budget-corner-list-of-budgets?layout=edit&id=3749

Congratulations to Hannah Ryan and Carley Salerno, who have been selected to serve as our student speakers at this year's graduation event for the APHS Class of 2020.

Each year, interested students submit anonymous speeches, with only a phone number, to the High School Office. These speeches are reviewed by a committee, two are selected, and then the phone numbers are called to find out who the speakers will be. Congratulations to Hannah and Carley!

Additionally, we are pleased to announce that our Senior Class Officers, in conjunction with their classmates, have selected our own AP Science teacher, Mr. Chris Reddy, to deliver our official commencement address to their class.

We are very excited to hear what all of these wonderful folks have to share, and look forward to celebrating the Class of 2020 together on the June 27.

Every 10 years, the United States Census collects data on everyone living in the United States of America. The census can shape many different aspects of our community. Census results help determine how billions of dollars in federal funding flow into states and communities each year. The results also determine how many seats in Congress each state gets.

Support for public school services and programs is just one of many reasons why an accurate 2020 Census count is crucial to our school district and our region.

Read more here: https://www.averillpark.k12.ny.us/news-archive-2019-2020/4140-2020-census-you-count

Seven Averill Park High School students were selected to participate in the 2020 Capital Region Media Arts Festival.

Congratulations to seniors Spencer Johnson, Logan Feathers and Anella Olsen; junior Gabriella Deck; and sophomores Alysha Costa, Jessica Barbour and Victoria Guynup.

Costa placed first in the Photography category: Landscape/Nature. Olsen placed third in the Design category: Digital Illustration. Johnson took third in the Design category: Digital Fine Art. Feathers placed third in the Photography category: Abstraction. Guynup earned Honorable Mention in the Photography category: Abstraction.

Please take a moment to view the virtual show at: https://mediaartsfestival2020.weebly.com/
